title: Understanding time
reviewers: Benjamin Rodrigues Peixoto, Karolyne Damasceno Brito

text: In addition to using the name America, we will also refer to the continent as Abya Yala, a term used by the indigenous peoples of the continent (Porto-Gonçalves, Carlos Walter, , pp. 39-43).

Introduction

Since my childhood, I've frequently encountered phrases incorporating the word "time". One classic expression that was echoed by various adults was: "the time is over". Another, a more poetic rendering, often heard among people (Rodrigues, W., Soares Filho, A. C., Vale, M. S. do, & Menezes, M. C., , pp. 12):

• The time asked for time: what time does time possess?
    The time responded, it does not have time to say
    the remaining time within time is the time available.

If you've had any involvement with 'Abrahamic religions' (Guy G. Stroumsa, ) at any point in your life, you might be familiar with Ecclesiastes chapter 3, which states that there is a "time for every pursuit under the heavens", illustrated with examples of different periods of time (Torah, Neviim u-Khetuvim. Twenty-four books of the Holy Scriptures carefully translated according to the Massoretic text, on the basis of the English version, after the best Jewish authorities, , pp. 876 - 877 ).

?
Reflexion 1: A question
All the preceding references have one thing in common: they allude to time, yet none offers a precise definition. So, what exactly is time?

The understanding about time

The comprehension of time has evolved over millennia, as explored by G. N. Bailey in his work (Bailey, G. N., ). . Within his discourse:
  • Pages 167 to 174 introduce a potential duality in understanding the universe and time's role in our lives.
  • On page 179, Bailey challenges conventional notions of the "present" and the "past", emphasizing temporal variations ranging from fleeting moments to millennia.
  • Pages 180 to 186 prompt us to consider vast time spans, such as the 100,000-year "glacial-interglacial cycle" alongside shorter periods like decades, underscoring time as a succession of events.
  • Page 187 notes that around 30,000 years ago, human intellectual development allowed for activities oriented towards the future.

It's crucial to note that the ability to project into the future doesn't necessarily entail a constant focus in that direction, as Jaakko Hintikka illustrates in his analysis of Greek concepts of time (Hintikka, J., , pp. 1 - 5, 14), highlighting the Greeks' deep immersion in the present.

Furthermore, defining periods of time linked to natural processes presents significant challenges (Bailey, G. N., , pp. 180 - 186). Ancient civilizations, in attempting to map the past, often attributed implausible durations to historical figures (Steenstrup, Troels, et al., ), such as Sumerian kings with millennial reigns (History Tracers Team, ; Cy, , 05:09). Millennia later, independent of authorship of the Pentateuch (Bajić, Monika, ; Dozeman, T. B., ; Cy, ), the Jewish tradition continued this trend, assigning patriarchs lifespans of centuries (Torah, Neviim u-Khetuvim. Twenty-four books of the Holy Scriptures carefully translated according to the Massoretic text, on the basis of the English version, after the best Jewish authorities, , pp. 7 - 8 ). These temporal discrepancies, contrasting with our lived experiences, differ markedly from Mesoamerican conceptions, as elaborated below (Ocampo, Estela; Bidon-Chanal, Carlos, , pp. 175).

Time Measurement

The measurement of time has always been crucial throughout human history, enabling us to determine the optimal moment for activities such as planting crops or births. In this section, we will delve into the Mesoamerican approach to time measurement.

The Maya calendar, along with those of other Mesoamerican cultures, was intricately linked with mathematics (Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , pp. 33 - 35 (ResearchGate) ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , pp. 33 - 35 (Revista) ; Catepillán, Ximena, ). Similar to the Gregorian calendar, Mesoamerican calendars divided time into specific periods:

PeriodsDescription
DayRepresents the time needed for the Earth to complete one rotation around its axis.
MonthComprised of periods of 20 days, with one period containing only 5 days to correct the solar year.
Tzolkín calendar (divinatory)A cycle of 260 days (13 x 20 = 260).
Haab calendar (civil)Consisting of 365 days (18 x 20 + 5 = 365).
Calendar wheelA cycle of 52 years where the Haab and Tzolkín calendars return to the same position, symbolizing the end of a cycle.
Table 1: Periods of Mesoamerican Time.
The Zapotecs also employed an additional division known as the "divinatory calendar", consisting of 4 periods of 65 days (Trejo, Jesús G., , pp. 20).
While not all eras are represented in the Aztecs' Sun Stone, it provides a visual representation of the previously discussed concepts (Ocampo, Estela; Bidon-Chanal, Carlos, , pp. 175):

Figure 1: Aztec Calendar on display at the National Museum of Anthropology in Mexico City (Museo Nacional de Antropologia - México ; INAH - MX, ).
Photo taken on , during a museum visit.

Furthermore, Mesoamericans developed additional structures to monitor the seasons of the year, known as E groups (Guderjan, T. H., ). These complex structures typically featured a pyramid with at least two additional buildings positioned ahead of it. The layout allowed for the observation of key celestial events: the summer solstice on the extreme left, the beginning of equinoxes in the center, and the winter solstice on the extreme right.

Figure 2: Section of the E Group at the Caracol archaeological site (Caracol Archaeological Project).
Photo taken on , during a site visit.

The genesis of time

One captivating aspect of the Maya calendar, along with those of other Mesoamerican civilizations, is their establishment of an origin point that traces back to the last "creation of the universe". This significant event is marked as August 13th, 3114 B.C., according to the Gregorian calendar (Graulich, Michel, ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , pp. 29 (ResearchGate) ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , pp. 29 (Revista)). The precise delineation of this starting point places these calendars ahead of many contemporary systems. Consequently, astronomical studies often adopt the Julian calendar due to its structural similarities with the Mesoamerican system (Julian Date Converter). Below is a list of calendars used in History Tracers Team, with the assistance of the source code by John Walker (Walker, John, ) identifying events that define its initial years:

CalendarBeginDescription
GregorianThe first year marks the birth of Jesus Christ, according to belief, and it also includes years before its "zero" year.
HebrewThis calendar commences with the "world creation", as per Jewish belief.
HispanicIt starts 38 years before the Gregorian calendar, due unknown reason.
IslamicThe calendar begins with the migration of Prophet Muhammad from Mecca to Medina.
Julian (Days)Number of days have elapsed since noon on Monday, 1st January of year 4713 B.C.E.
MesoamericanA cyclic calendar that counts days since its first day, according to Mesoamerican beliefs.
PersaAdopted in 1925, this solar calendar is no longer in use. It also starts with the Prophet Muhammad migration.
French RevolutionOriginating from the French Revolution, this calendar is no longer utilized.
ShakaThe Indian Civil calendar, which starts with the "Shaka Era".

Table 2: Commencement dates of calendars utilized in History Tracers Team, categorized by distinct algorithms.
The abbreviations A.E.C, B.C.E (Before Common Era), and negative years serve as generalizations for representing eras preceding the initial days of the calendars.

Research by Orlando Josué C. To learn the names of Mesoamerican numbers in the Tseltal language and their usage in literature, we recommend reading 'Gramática Tseltal' by Aurelio Hernández Mendoza and Felipa Pérez López (Hernández Mendoza, Aurelio & Pérez López, Felipa, , pp. 251 - 260).
Furthermore, Mesoamerican calendars exhibit coherent cycles spanning millennia, a feature absent in Western worldviews (Ocampo, Estela; Bidon-Chanal, Carlos, , pp. 175).

The quest to uncover the origins of time transcends epochs of distant past. Edwin Hubble's groundbreaking demonstration of the universe's expansion (Hubble, Edwin, ), led to the compelling conclusion that the cosmos likely emerged from a singularity. This pivotal discovery ignited a flurry of scientific inquiry, culminating in estimates of the universe's age ranging between 11 and 18 billion years (D’Antona, F., Caloi, V., & Mazzitelli, I., ; , Chaboyer, B., ; Hossenfelder, Sabine , ). We have also been able to estimate with good precision the Earth's age at around 4 billion years (Zhang, Y., ). Given that such vast timescales far exceed the scope of our current calendars, it is possible that we will proceed with current calendars.

?
Reflection 2: The plurality of temporal perspectives
Across diverse cultures, time is perceived and measured through distinct lenses. Does time possess a unique manifestation for each observer?

Exploring time

Mistakes often accompany attempts to measure time accurately. Below, we examine several examples from various sections of History Tracers Team that underscore these challenges:

Origins

In recent years, significant strides have been made in our comprehension of time's origins. While civilizations like the Mesoamerican developed calendars capable of representing millions of years (Walker, John, ), others crafted calendars reflecting millennia. Discrepancies between these data sets may stem from the contexts in which the calendars were created.

The end

When we tend to opposite direction, we lie the notion of the "end of times". Indigenous peoples in America (Abya Yala) may perceive this through a lens influenced by the colonizers' vision of the apocalypse (History Tracers Team, , Who claimed that indigenous peoples are inherently different? ; Timmer, David E., , pp. 477-478). Contemporary conceptions of the end of times have evolved far beyond the simplistic views held by past observers, encompassing possibilities such as universal contraction or cyclical recreation (Penrose, R., , pp. 69 - 84 ; Hossenfelder, Sabine, ; PBS, ).

Interim periods

In the absence of defined starting and ending points, the delineation of intermediate periods becomes fraught with complexity. As noted by G. N. Bailey (Bailey, G. N., ), determining long and short periods of time is inherently imprecise. For instance, the misinterpretation of historical events surrounding Garcia Roiz Paes' defamations per generations, conduct people to wrong conclusion about his Jewish origin (History Tracers Team, , Garcia Roiz Paes). Analogous mistake happens with Antonio Raposo Tavares (History Tracers Team, , Antonio Raposo Tavares).

Calendar confusion

Confusion regarding the calendars used in historical documents, such as those associated with Gonçalo Trastamires' wife (History Tracers Team, , Gonçalo Trastamires). It is possible that some users confused documentation written with Hispanic date believing to ber Gregorian dates.

Retroactive forecasting

Narratives often seek to establish connections with historical figures that defy verification. For instance, Gaio's suggestion regarding Menaia Ribeiro's lineage to Sisebuto serves as a cautionary tale against unsubstantiated claims (History Tracers Team, , Menaia Ribeiro).

Living in the past

Knowledge continually evolves with new discoveries (History Tracers Team, , Scientific method), yet some cling to ancient texts without regard for updated evidence. The case of Garcia Roiz's [supposed] wife exemplifies this, with initial assumptions giving way to a more nuanced understanding (History Tracers Team, , Isabel Velho ; History Tracers Team, , Isabel Velho II).

Conclusion

We cannot critique those who devised calendars based on shorter periods or those who uncritically accept historical texts overlook, because probably they learned to do this.
This section provides a broad overview of temporal complexities and common pitfalls, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of time and text interpretation in subsequent sections.

text.question: Have we truly grasped the concept of time since we began to use it?
text.additionalInfo: The perception of day and night is observed in different cultures, evidenced by the development of various calendars. Consequently, our understanding of time in the 21st century is much broader than when we first began to understand cycles like days.

text.question: Did indigenous peoples develop calendars and erect monuments to measure time?
text.additionalInfo: Diverse texts and constructions across the American (Abya Yala) continent show that Indigenous people developed different methods to measure time.

text.question: Do various cultures have calendars that originate from a shared starting point?
text.additionalInfo: Due to differing worldviews, the starting points of calendars vary among cultures.

text.question: While the Gregorian, Islamic, and Hebrew calendars have distinct origins, do the civilizations employing them share certain beliefs?
text.additionalInfo: The three mentioned calendars are used by people with shared beliefs but have different origins. The Gregorian calendar is a correction of the Julian calendar, beginning in January of the year of Jesus Christ's birth according to Christian beliefs. The Islamic calendar counts time from the migration of the prophet Muhammad. Finally, the Jewish calendar starts from what is believed to be the recent creation of the world.

text.question: Do the Julian and Mesoamerican calendars both share the characteristic of to be used to count days from a specific initial date?Do the Julian and Mesoamerican calendars both share the characteristic of to be used to count days from a specific initial date?
text.additionalInfo: The Julian calendar is used in astronomy to count days from a specific date, while the Mesoamerican calendar counts days from a recent creation according to their beliefs, which is part of a cycle of creations.
